newsitem.title: INDIA: EU says proposed rice regulation not to hit India.
newsitem.headline: EU says proposed rice regulation not to hit India.

text.p: A proposed new rice regulation agreed by the European Union (EU) was optional and Indian Basmati rice exporters need not opt for it, the EU said on Friday.
"The Cumulative Recovery System (CRS) is only an option and not an obligation," an EU statement said referring to reports in India expressing apprehension over the proposed rule.
"If India so wishes, high-quality Basmati rice can continue to be eligible for the $300 duty reduction per tonne without a quantitative limit as has been the case until now," the statement said.
Last month, Indian rice exporters said they would lose about 70 percent of their Basmati exports to the European Union if the new regulation was approved.
Indian Basmati rice is now entering the EU with a duty reduction of $300 per tonne without quantitative restrictions.
Indian exporters fear that the enforcement of the CRS with effect from May 15 will tilt the balance against India which is the largest exporter of Basmati rice to the EU.

"The CRS is intended to ensure that if traders can prove that under the EC's representative price system, they have paid import duties above the EC's Uruguay Round bindings, they can recover the excess duty paid," the EU statement said.
India's Basmati rice exports to the EU in fiscal 1996/97 (April/March) were estimated at 75,000 tonnes, about 80 percent of the EU's total Basmati imports.
